maml:description.maml:para: Upload appliance backup file to restore its configuration.

Using this cmdlet will initiate a restore of the appliance to the backup file specified. Starts a restore operation from the backup file already uploaded to the appliance. Only one restore operation can run at a time. There is no way to cancel a restore once it has been started. The restore operation is destructive. Any configuration changes not included in the backup file will be lost. The appliance will raise alerts for any inconsistencies detected after the restore. If an unrecoverable error is detected during the restore, then the appliance will be set to the factory reset mode.
Restoring from a backup is a disruptive action:
• The appliance restarts and users cannot log in to the appliance during the restore process. All users are logged out and their work is lost. • To prevent duplicate identifiers on the network, server hardware configurations are cleared if an associated server profile is not in the backup. • Server profiles that have been modified since the backup was taken are flagged with this message: 'Server profile settings conflict with the server hardware configuration'. To reapply the server profile configuration and restore network connectivity, you must unassign all flagged server profiles and then individually reassign the server profiles to the server hardware. • To prevent unintentional assignment of duplicate addresses or identifiers, all address and identifier ranges are disabled after the post-restore process completes. The appliance automatically re-creates replacement address and identifier ranges.
Aliases [-File] The full path and file name of the appliance configuration backup file.
Aliases [-File] The full path and file name of the appliance configuration backup file.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: The restore task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVRestore "C:\Users\me\Documents\appliance_backup_2013-11-01_110203.bkp" Upload a backup file to restore in the appliance.

maml:description.maml:para: Create storage volume template.
This cmdlet supports creating Storage Volume Templates, which are then used to provision Storage Volumes.
Aliases [-name] Storage Volume Template name
Optional. Provide the description for the Storage Volume Template
Specify the Storage Pool (aka CPG) the Storage Volume Template will be associated with. Storage Pool must already be managed by OneView.
Aliases [-size] Max volume capacity in GB. e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to enable Thick volume provisioning. Omit to specify Thin storage provisioning.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume Template as a Shareable resource for shared volume access.
Aliases [-name] Storage Volume Template name
Optional. Provide the description for the Storage Volume Template
Specify the Storage Pool (aka CPG) the Storage Volume Template will be associated with. Storage Pool must already be managed by OneView.
Aliases [-size] Max volume capacity in GB. e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to enable Thick volume provisioning. Omit to specify Thin storage provisioning.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume Template as a Shareable resource for shared volume access.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Created Storage Volume Template resource.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplate -templateName yellow-svt -storagePool yellow -capacity 40 Create a new Storage Volume Template, setting the max size to 40GB, Thin Provisioning and Private.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $storageVolTemplate = New-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplate -templateName vmware-shared-svt -storagePool R5-CPG12 -capacity 250 -shared Create a new Storage Volume Template, setting the max size to 250GB, Thin Provisioning and Shareable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $storagePool = Get-HPOVStoragePool R5-CPG12 PS C:\> $storageVolTemplate = New-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplate -templateName vmware-shared-svt -storagePool $storagePool -capacity 250 -shared
Use the Get-HPOVStoragePool cmdlet to get the 'R5-CPG12' pool, and create a new Storage Volume Template, setting the max size to 250GB, Thin Provisioning and Shareable.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a Storage Volume resource.

This cmdlet will help create a Storage Volume resource on a managed Storage System. The volume can be created by specifying the Storage Pool or an existing Storage Volume Template. When the Storage Pool name is not unique, you can either use the -StorageSystem parameter, or pass via the pipeline the Storage Pool from Get-HPOVStoragePool.
If the Storage Volume Template Global Policy is enabled, a valid Storage Volume Template must be provided.
Aliases [-Name] Storage Volume Name. Device Volume created on the storage system will be this name without spaces.
Optional. Provide a description for the volume.
Aliases [-pool, -PoolName] Required. Storage Pool URI, name or resource object.
Optional. When the Storage Pool name is not unique, specify the Storage System name the pool is managed/associate with.
Aliases [-size] Max volume capacity in GB. e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to enable Thick volume provisioning. Omit to specify Thin storage provisioning. Default: Thin
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private

If present, indicates that the volume will persist when the profile using this volume is deleted (Persistent Volume). If not, then the volume will be deleted when the profile using this volume is deleted (Ephemeral Volume).
Aliases [-Name] Storage Volume Name. Device Volume created on the storage system will be this name without spaces.
Aliases [-template, -svt] Optional. Specify the Storage Volume Template Name, URI or Resource.
Aliases [-size] Max volume capacity in GB. e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private

If present, indicates that the volume will persist when the profile using this volume is deleted (Persistent Volume). If not, then the volume will be deleted when the profile using this volume is deleted (Ephemeral Volume).
Aliases [-Name] Storage Volume Name. Device Volume created on the storage system will be this name without spaces.
Optional. Provide a description for the volume.
Aliases [-pool, -PoolName] Required. Storage Pool URI, name or resource object.
Optional. When the Storage Pool name is not unique, specify the Storage System name the pool is managed/associate with.
Aliases [-template, -svt] Optional. Specify the Storage Volume Template Name, URI or Resource.
Aliases [-size] Max volume capacity in GB. e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to enable Thick volume provisioning. Omit to specify Thin storage provisioning. Default: Thin
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private

If present, indicates that the volume will persist when the profile using this volume is deleted (Persistent Volume). If not, then the volume will be deleted when the profile using this volume is deleted (Ephemeral Volume).
Storage Pool Name or URI
Storage Pool resource object
Async create task

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVStorageVolume -name TestVol1 -PoolName PoolR1 -Size 60 Create a 60GB private, thin provisioned volume named 'TestVol1' from the 'PoolR1' Storage Pool.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVStoragePool PoolR1 | New-HPOVStorageVolume -name TestVol1 PoolR1 -Size 60 Get the 'PoolR1' Storage Pool resource and pipe it to create a 60GB private, thin provisioned volume named 'TestVol1'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVStoragePool PoolR1 -StorageSystem 3ParSys1 | New-HPOVStorageVolume -name TestVol1 -Size 60 Get the 'PoolR1' Storage Pool resource and pipe it to create a 60GB private, thin provisioned volume named 'TestVol1'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVStorageVolume -name TestVol1 -StoragePool PoolR1 -StorageSystem 3ParSys1 -Size 60 Create a 60GB private, thin provisioned volume named 'TestVol1' from the 'PoolR1' Storage Pool resource that is managed by '3ParSys1'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $svt = Get-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplate SVT_120GB_R5 PS C:\> $New-HPOVStorageVolume testvol3 -volumetemplate $svt -capacity 90 | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete Create a 90GB volume named 'TestVol1', using the 'SVT_120GB_R5' Storage Volume Template, then wait for volume to be provisioned.

maml:description.maml:para: Generate and download Support Dumps.

Support Dumps are required when an issue is encountered and HP Support requests one to be generated. There are two different Support Dumps:
1. Appliance 2. Logical Interconnect
The Appliance Support Dump contains important log files about the appliance, but excludes the Logical Interconnect logs.
The full path to where the Support Dump will be saved to. The downloaded file name will be generated by the appliance. If the directory does not exist, it will be created.

The type of Support Dump to collect. Possible values are:
1. appliance 2. li
Specify the Logical Interconnect Name the Support Dump will be generated for.
The full path to where the Support Dump will be saved to. The downloaded file name will be generated by the appliance. If the directory does not exist, it will be created.
Aliases [-liobject, -li] Specify the Logical Interconnect URI or Object the Support Dump will be generated for, from pipeline.
The full path to where the Support Dump will be saved to. The downloaded file name will be generated by the appliance. If the directory does not exist, it will be created.

The type of Support Dump to collect. Possible values are:
1. appliance 2. li
Specify the Logical Interconnect Name the Support Dump will be generated for.
Aliases [-liobject, -li] Specify the Logical Interconnect URI or Object the Support Dump will be generated for, from pipeline.

dev:type.maml:name: Accepts pipeline input from Get-HPOVLogicalInterconnect only.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVSupportDump c:\temp appliance This command will save the Appliance support dump to C:\Temp

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVSupportDump c:\temp li ENC1-LI This command will save the Logical Interconnect ENC1-LI to C:\Temp

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVlogicalinterconnect ENC1-LI | New-HPOVSupportDump c:\temp Accepting the response from Get-HPOVLogicalInterconnect CMDLET

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVlogicalinterconnect | % { New-HPOVSupportDump c:\temp li $_ } Accepting the response from Get-HPOVLogicalInterconnect CMDLET for all Logical Interconnects and creating support dumps for all.

maml:description.maml:para: Create an Unmanaged Device.

HP OneView provides administrators with the capability to define unmanaged devices to them place within Racks, in order to provide a more realistic and complete data center layout. Creating a device does not provide the ability to manage it from HP Oneview. The administrator will need to specify static characteristics of the device being added. The unmanaged device can then be assigned into the appropriate rack manually.
The name of the Unmanaged Device.
The device model.
Rack Unit height of the Unmanaged Device.
The maximum power consumption of the Unmanaged Device.
The name of the Unmanaged Device.
The device model.
Rack Unit height of the Unmanaged Device.
The maximum power consumption of the Unmanaged Device.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVUnmanagedDevice -name "Unmanaged-SRVR1" -model "ProLiant DL380 G6" -height 2 -maxpower 750 Create a new unmanaged server device.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-HPOVUnmanagedDevice -name "HPN5900CP1" -model "HPN 5900CP" -height 1 -maxpower 260 Create a new unmanaged switch device.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new Uplink Set in a Logical Interconnect Group.

Create a new Uplink Set in a Logical Interconnect Group. The Logical Interconnect Group must already exist. Multiple networks and multiple uplink ports can be assigned to the uplink set during creation.
Logical Interconnect Group Name to create the Uplink set for.
Aliases [-usName] Logical Uplink set Name

Aliases [-usType] Uplink set Type. Accepted values are
• Ethernet (Default) • FibreChannel • Tunnel • Untagged
Aliases [-usNetworks] Array of Ethernet Network Names
Aliases [-usNativeEthNetwork, -Native, -PVID] The valid name of the Native Ethernet Network that is a member of the usNetworks parameter.

Aliases [-usUplinkPorts] Array of uplink ports with "BAYID:FacePlatePortID".
FlexFabric e.g. @("BAY1:X1","BAY1:X2") or "BAY1:X5","BAY2:X5" VC Fibre Channel e.g. @("BAY3:1","BAY3:2") or "BAY3:1","BAY3:2"

Aliases [-usEthMode] Sets the LACP mode on the uplink ports. Valid for ETHERNET Uplinks only. Acceopted Values:
• Auto (Default) • Failover

Set the LACP Timer value, which sets the lacpdu frequecy to the LACP peer. Accepted values:
• Long (Default) • Short

Specify the Fibre Channel Uplink Port speed. Accepted values:
• Auto (Default) • 2 • 4 • 8

maml:description.maml:para: Remove an enclosure group.
Deletes an enclosure group from the appliance. An enclosure group cannot be deleted if any enclosures are currently part of that enclosure group.

The Enclosure Group object(s), name(s) or uri(s) to be removed from management.
Collection of Enclousre Resource Objects
Single Enclosure Resource Object.
Async removal Task.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a Logical Interconnect Group.

Force remove succeeds even if there are network connectivity issues or resource errors. -Force is not a PowerShell option, rather an HP OneView API feature. This does not override the -Confirm PowerShell option.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVNetworkSet | Remove-HPOVNetworkSet Search for all network sets and remove them from appliance.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove pending or staged appliance update.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove power device (iPDU)
Removes a power device (iPDU) from appliance management.
The Power Device object(s), name(s) or uri(s) to be removed from management.
Set to $true to force-remove the power device. Force-removing will succeed even when there are connectivity issues or resource errors.
The Power Device object(s), name(s) or uri(s) to be removed from management.
Set to $true to force-remove the power device. Force-removing will succeed even when there are connectivity issues or resource errors.

Async remove task.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove existing resource(s).

Removes a resource identified by either the resource uri or a resource object. Remove-HPOVResource can be called with either -nameOrUri or -resource.
*** This cmdlet will not prompt for delete confirmation. Please use with caution. ***
Aliases [-name, -uri] The name or uri of the resource to be deleted.

Optional. Invoke switch force-delete the resource when OneView can no longer communicate with the resource and removal is needed. -Force is not a PowerShell option, rather an HP OneView API feature. This does not override the -Confirm PowerShell option. Not all resources support force-delete.
Aliases [-ro] A resource object to be deleted. The resource object should first be retrieved by a call to a Get-HPOVxxx call.

Optional. Invoke switch force-delete the resource when OneView can no longer communicate with the resource and removal is needed. -Force is not a PowerShell option, rather an HP OneView API feature. This does not override the -Confirm PowerShell option. Not all resources support force-delete.
Aliases [-ro] A resource object to be deleted. The resource object should first be retrieved by a call to a Get-HPOVxxx call.
Aliases [-name, -uri] The name or uri of the resource to be deleted.

Optional. Invoke switch force-delete the resource when OneView can no longer communicate with the resource and removal is needed. -Force is not a PowerShell option, rather an HP OneView API feature. This does not override the -Confirm PowerShell option. Not all resources support force-delete.
A valid resource object first retrieved by a call to a Get-HPOV*** cmdlet
Removal async task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-HPOVResource -nameOrUri "/rest/resource/1234-5678-9123" Removes the resource specified by the URI.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-HPOVResource -nameOrUri "ServerProfile-A" Removes the resource named "ServerProfile-A". If multiple resources exist with the name "ServerProfile-A", an error is returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $MyResourceObject = send-hpovrequest "/rest/resource/1234-5678-9123" PS C:\> Remove-HPOVResource -resource $MyResourceObject
Removes the resource $MyReSourceObject.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove SAN Manager.
This cmdlet is used to remove the specified SAN Manager from the appliance.
Single SAN Manager resource object
Removal async task resource

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-HPOVSanManager bna.contoso.com Remove the bna.contoso.com SAN Manager from the appliance.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a rackmount server from the appliance.

Removes a physical server object from appliance management.
The server object can be specified by its name or its full URI on the appliance by using the -nameOrUri parameter. It can also be supplied as an object by using the -resource parameter the object variable can be piped to Remove-HPOVServer.
Blade servers can only be removed by removing the enclosure, of phyhsically removing the blade from the enclosure.
Aliases ['uri','name'] The Server object(s), name(s) or uri(s) to be removed from management.

Use to force-remove the server.
For example, if the server is gone or managed by a different appliance, force-remove will remove the server from this appliance without needing to update the iLO.
Aliases ['uri','name'] The Server object(s), name(s) or uri(s) to be removed from management.

Use to force-remove the server.
For example, if the server is gone or managed by a different appliance, force-remove will remove the server from this appliance without needing to update the iLO.
Provide the Server Resource Object
Async removal task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $task = Remove-HPOVServer -name "Server-1234" -force PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task.uri
Force-remove the server specifed by name. Wait for remove to complete.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $server = Get-HPOVServer -name "Server-1234" PS C:\> Remove-HPOVServer $server -confirm:$false
Remove the server specifed by $server. Disable confirmation prompt.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $server = Get-HPOVServer -name "Server-1234" PS C:\> Remove-HPOVServer $server -confirm:$false -force
Remove the server specifed by $server. Disable confirmation prompt, and force remove the server.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVServer | Remove-HPOVServer Search for all rackmount servers and remove them from appliance.

maml:description.maml:para: Restart an HP OneView appliance.

This cmdlet will allow the administrator to restart/reboot the appliance. Restarting the appliance will cause all users to be disconnected and all ongoing tasks to be interrupted.
Only the Inrfrastructure (Full) Administrator may restart the appliance.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Warning message the appliance is stopping
Generated error message

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-HPOVMgmt appliance.contoso.com Administrator P@ssw0rd PS C:\> Restart-HPOVAppliance Restart the appliance

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Restart-HPOVAppliance -confirm:$false Restart the appliance without confirmation.

• BLADE_TO_PROFILE • PROFILE_TO_SERVER_HARDWARE_TYPE • RACK_TO_PHYSICAL_DEVICE • BLADE_TO_INTERCONNECT • ENCLOSURE_GROUP_TO_ENCLOSURE • ENCLOSURE_GROUP_TO_LOGICAL_INTERCONNECT_GROUP • ENCLOSURE_TO_BLADE • ENCLOSURE_TO_SWITCH • LOGICAL_SWITCH_TO_LOGICAL_UPLINK • SWITCH_TO_LOGICAL_SWITCH • SERVER_PROFILES_TO_FC_NETWORKS • SERVER_PROFILES_TO_NETWORKS • STORAGE_SYSTEM_TO_STORAGE_POOL • FC_NETWORK_TO_STORAGE_SYSTEM • STORAGE_POOL_TO_VOLUME • STORAGE_POOL_TO_VOLUME_TEMPLATE

The maximum number of resource index entries to be returned. Defaults to 50.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends a request to the management appliance

Receives the request input, properly constructs and formats the request header and body and sends the request to the management appliance. This is the main cmdlet that interacts with the appliance.
The message body can contain valid JSON data, with the correct URI and accepted HTTP method accepted by the target resource manager. Please see the on-appliance Resource Model for more information (https://[appliance_IP]/help/cic/en/content/images/api/.)
The uri that identifies the required resource on the appliance.

Optional. The request HTTP Method.
• "GET" (default) to get a resource from the appliance (read) • "POST" to create a new resource • "PUT" to modify a resource (write) • "DELETE" to delete a resource
Optional. Body for the request. Required if the method is POST or PUT.
Optional. For GETs on resource collections, this specifies the starting index in the collection. If not specified, collection members starting from the beginning are returned.
Optional. For GETs on resource collections, this specifies the number of collection members to return. If not specified, all members of the collection are returned from this function.
Optional. If additional headers are needed/required than the defaults, include header names and values within a Hashtable.
The uri that identifies the required resource on the appliance.

Optional. The request HTTP Method.
• "GET" (default) to get a resource from the appliance (read) • "POST" to create a new resource • "PUT" to modify a resource (write) • "DELETE" to delete a resource
Optional. Body for the request. Required if the method is POST or PUT.
Optional. For GETs on resource collections, this specifies the starting index in the collection. If not specified, collection members starting from the beginning are returned.
Optional. For GETs on resource collections, this specifies the number of collection members to return. If not specified, all members of the collection are returned from this function.
Optional. If additional headers are needed/required than the defaults, include header names and values within a Hashtable.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: If collection of resources (.i.e. GET /rest/ethernet-networks)
Single object returned from appliance
If no resources are found, a PsCustomObject is returned that contains:

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-HPOVRequest "/rest/enclosures" Returns all the enclosure objects managed by the appliance.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $e = Send-HPOVRequest "/rest/enclosures/SGH2X6J1" PS C:\> $e.name = "New Name" PS C:\> Send-HPOVRequest $e.uri "PUT" $e
Updates the name of the enclosure object specified by the uri.

maml:description.maml:para: Assign an alert to a user.

The user this alert is to be assigned to. The alert will be assigned to no user if this parameter is omitted.
The alert to be modified

maml:description.maml:para: Change status of an alert.

Alerts can be in one of two administratively controlled states: Active or Cleared. This CMDLET allows the administrator to change the status of an alert to either Active or Cleared.
In order for an Administrator to change the status of an Alert, the Administrator must be assigned to the respective resource role (Network, Server, Storage, or Infrastructure.)
The alert to be cleared. Can be URI or resource object.
Notes of the action for the alert.
Change the alert to 'Cleared' status.
Change the alert to 'Active' status.
The alert to be cleared. Can be URI or resource object.
Notes of the action for the alert.
Change the alert to 'Cleared' status.
Change the alert to 'Active' status.
The alert to be cleared. Can be URI or resource object.
Notes of the action for the alert.
Change the alert to 'Cleared' status.
Change the alert to 'Active' status.
Alert Name or URI.
Alert resource object (i.e. Get-HPOVAlert).
The updated alert.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Clear-HPOVAlert /rest/alerts/11 -cleared Clears the alert.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVAlert

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVApplianceNetworkConfig -hostname "appliance1.my.com" -ipv4Type "DHCP" -ipv6Type "UNCONFIGURE" -domainName "my.com" This example passes in updated values to set for the appliance networking configuration.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVApplianceNetworkConfig -importFile "c:\myNetworkInput.json" This example passes the name of an input file containing JSON formatted properties and values for the appliance network configuration.

maml:description.maml:para: Accept the EULA and set support access for the specified appliance.
Accept the EULA and set support access for the specified appliance.
Set to 'yes' to allow HP suport access to the appliance, otherwise set to 'no'.
The hostname or IP address of the HP OneView appliance. If not specified, a connection must already be established with Connect-HPOVMgmt.
Set to 'yes' to allow HP suport access to the appliance, otherwise set to 'no'.
The hostname or IP address of the HP OneView appliance. If not specified, a connection must already be established with Connect-HPOVMgmt.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Version and current support access state.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Connect-HPOVMgmt appliance.contoso.com administrator MyPassw0rd PS C:\> Set-HPOVEulaStatus -supportAccess "yes"
Connects to a specific appliance, accepting the EULA and enable Support Access.

maml:description.maml:para: Change the initial password of the Administrator user account.
Changes the initial default password of the Administrator local appliance account to the supplied new password during first time setup (FTS.)
The name of the user account to be updated. Normally Administrator.
Current default password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.
New password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.
The name of the user account to be updated. Normally Administrator.
Current default password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.
New password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.
The name of the user account to be updated. Normally Administrator.
Current default password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.
New password for this account. Will prompt for password if not supplied.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVInitialPassword Administrator Change the Administrator password, and prompted for both the original and new password.

maml:description.maml:para: Assign or change roles for LDAP Groups.
Changes current roles of an LDAP Group with a given set of roles. You must provide the list of all roles the LDAP Group should be set to, and not a subset of roles.
Aliases [-d, -domain, -directory] LDAP/Active Directory Domain Name
Aliases [-g, -group, -name] Directroy Group to add

Aliases [-r, -role] The role(s) to assign to the Directroy Group, in System.Array format. Accepted values are:
• Read only • Infrastructure administrator • Server administrator • Storage administrator • Network administrator • Backup administrator
e.g. $roles = "Server administrator","Network administrator"
Aliases [-u] Username to authenticate with
Aliases [-p] User account password
Aliases [-d, -domain, -directory] LDAP/Active Directory Domain Name
Aliases [-g, -group, -name] Directroy Group to add

Aliases [-r, -role] The role(s) to assign to the Directroy Group, in System.Array format. Accepted values are:
• Read only • Infrastructure administrator • Server administrator • Storage administrator • Network administrator • Backup administrator
e.g. $roles = "Server administrator","Network administrator"
Aliases [-u] Username to authenticate with
Aliases [-p] User account password
Directory User Account password
Updated LDAP Group object with new role assignment(s).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVLdapGroupRole -d Domain1 -GroupName "MY Directory Group1" -roles "Server administrator" -u 'Sarah Peterson' Add "MY Directory Group1" from Domain1 with Server Administrator role and prompt for password for group validation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $roles = "Server administrator","Backup administrator" PS C:\> $password = convertto-securestring -asplaintext "password123890" -force PS C:\> Set-HPOVLdapGroupRole -d Domain1 -GroupName "MY Directory Group1" -roles $roles -u 'Sarah Peterson' -p $password Set "MY Directory Group1" from Domain1 with Server and Backup administrator roles, and specify password for group validation.

maml:description.maml:para: Enable or Disable Automated SAN Zoning.
This cmdlet is used to Enable or Disable a Managed SAN resource on the appliance. Disabling a Managed SAN will prevent the appliance from configuring FC Zones.
Managed SAN Name, URI or Object.
(DEPRICATED - Please use -ZoningPolicy parameter.) Enable Automated Zoning for the specified Managed SAN. When used, the default Zone Policy 'SingleInitiatorAllTargets' is set.

Policy setting that affects the way that zones are created. Allowed values:
• NoZoning - Disable all automated zoning on the SAN and ignore policy settings related to zoning. • SingleInitiatorAllTargets - Create one zone per initiator containing all targets connected to that initiator. • SingleInitiatorSingleStorageSystem - Similar to SingleInitiatorAllTargets except that separate zones are created for targets that reside on different storage systems.
Enable aliases to be created for initiators, targets and target groups based on the specified name formats

Format to use for initiator alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {hostName}, {initiatorName}, {initiatorWwn}.
Example: "initiator_{hostname}_{initiatorName}"

Format to use for target group (ex. storage system port group) alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {storageSystemName}, {targetGroupName}.
Example: "TargetGroup_{storageSystemName}_{targetGroupName}"

Format to use for target (ex. storage system port) alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {storageSystemName}, {targetName}.
Example: "Target_{storageSystemName}_{targetName}"

Format to use when naming new and updated zones. The following built-in variables can be used: {hostName}, {initiatorName}, {initiatorWwn}, {storageSystemName}, {targetName}, {targetGroupName}
Example: "{initiatorWwn}_{initiatorName}"
Managed SAN Name, URI or Object.
(DEPRICATED - Please use -ZoningPolicy parameter.) Enable Automated Zoning for the specified Managed SAN. When used, the default Zone Policy 'SingleInitiatorAllTargets' is set.

Policy setting that affects the way that zones are created. Allowed values:
• NoZoning - Disable all automated zoning on the SAN and ignore policy settings related to zoning. • SingleInitiatorAllTargets - Create one zone per initiator containing all targets connected to that initiator. • SingleInitiatorSingleStorageSystem - Similar to SingleInitiatorAllTargets except that separate zones are created for targets that reside on different storage systems.
Disable aliases to be created for initiators, targets and target groups based on the specified name formats
Managed SAN Name, URI or Object.
(DEPRICATED - Please use -ZoningPolicy parameter.) Disable Automated Zoning for the specified Managed SAN.

Policy setting that affects the way that zones are created. Allowed values:
• NoZoning - Disable all automated zoning on the SAN and ignore policy settings related to zoning. • SingleInitiatorAllTargets - Create one zone per initiator containing all targets connected to that initiator. • SingleInitiatorSingleStorageSystem - Similar to SingleInitiatorAllTargets except that separate zones are created for targets that reside on different storage systems.
Managed SAN Name, URI or Object.
(DEPRICATED - Please use -ZoningPolicy parameter.) Enable Automated Zoning for the specified Managed SAN. When used, the default Zone Policy 'SingleInitiatorAllTargets' is set.
(DEPRICATED - Please use -ZoningPolicy parameter.) Disable Automated Zoning for the specified Managed SAN.

Policy setting that affects the way that zones are created. Allowed values:
• NoZoning - Disable all automated zoning on the SAN and ignore policy settings related to zoning. • SingleInitiatorAllTargets - Create one zone per initiator containing all targets connected to that initiator. • SingleInitiatorSingleStorageSystem - Similar to SingleInitiatorAllTargets except that separate zones are created for targets that reside on different storage systems.
Enable aliases to be created for initiators, targets and target groups based on the specified name formats
Disable aliases to be created for initiators, targets and target groups based on the specified name formats

Format to use for initiator alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {hostName}, {initiatorName}, {initiatorWwn}.
Example: "initiator_{hostname}_{initiatorName}"

Format to use for target group (ex. storage system port group) alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {storageSystemName}, {targetGroupName}.
Example: "TargetGroup_{storageSystemName}_{targetGroupName}"

Format to use for target (ex. storage system port) alias names. The following built-in variables can be used: {storageSystemName}, {targetName}.
Example: "Target_{storageSystemName}_{targetName}"

Format to use when naming new and updated zones. The following built-in variables can be used: {hostName}, {initiatorName}, {initiatorWwn}, {storageSystemName}, {targetName}, {targetGroupName}
Example: "{initiatorWwn}_{initiatorName}"
Single Resource
Multiple Resources
Single resource Name or URI
Single Resource
Multiple Resources

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVManagedSan Fabric_A -ZoningPolicy SingleInitiatorAllTargets Enable Automated SAN Zoning for 'Fabric_A'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVManagedSan Fabric_A -ZoningPolicy NoZoning Disable Automated SAN Zoning for 'Fabric_A'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVManagedSan | Set-HPOVManagedSan -ZoningPolicy SingleInitiatorAllTargets Enable Automated SAN Zoning for all managed SAN Fabrics

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing network set.
Modify a network set and/or its connection information.
The name of the network set resource to be modified.
The updated name value of the Network Set.
An array containing the updated list of networks. May contain Network Names or URI's.
Aliases [-untagged, -native, -untaggedNetworkUri] The Name or URI of the Untaggged, or Native Network for the Network Set.
The updated Typical or Preferred bandwidth, in Mbps.
The updated MAximum bandwidth, in Mbps.
The name of the network set resource to be modified.
The updated name value of the Network Set.
An array containing the updated list of networks. May contain Network Names or URI's.
Aliases [-untagged, -native, -untaggedNetworkUri] The Name or URI of the Untaggged, or Native Network for the Network Set.
The updated Typical or Preferred bandwidth, in Mbps.
The updated MAximum bandwidth, in Mbps.
Single Network Set resource
Update Network Set resource task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $netset = Get-HPOVNetworkSet "Set-1" PS C:\> $netset.maximumBandwidth = 5000 PS C:\> $netset.typicalBandwidth = 3000 PS C:\> Set-HPOVNetworkSet $netset Modify "Set-1" to be maximum bandwidth of 5000.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVNetworkSet NetSet-1 | Set-HPOVNetworkSet -name NewNetSet-1 -networks @(bluenet,rednet,greennet) -untagged bluenet Update 'NetSet-1' with a new name, adjust the networks, and set 'bluenet' as the Untagged Network.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing network.

Modify a network and it's attributes information. Use this cmdlet to change the Network Name, Purpose, Enable or Disable Smartlink, Enable or Disable Private Network, and adjust the allocated bandwidth.
The network resources new Name value.
Use this parameter to add a new prefix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the prefix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.
Use this parameter to add a new suffix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the suffix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.
Preferred amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.
Maximum amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.

The time in seconds the appliance waits before reconnecting to a link that was previously offline (Login redistribution). This interval prevents connection loss due to reconnecting to a link that is unstable (going online and offline repeatedly).

Used for login balancing when logins are not distributed evenly over the Fibre Channel links (for example, when an uplink that was down becomes available).
True: Login redistribution is initiated automatically when the link stability time expires. False: Login redistribution must be initiated manually.
Optional. Managed SAN Name or URI.
The network resources new Name value.
Use this parameter to add a new prefix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the prefix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.
Use this parameter to add a new suffix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the suffix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.

A description of the network's role within the logical interconnect. Accepted values in string format are:
• General • Management • VMMigration • FaultTolerance
Enable or Disable Smartlink within the Ethernet Network.
Enable or Disable Private Network within the Ethernet Network.
Preferred amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.
Maximum amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.
The network resources new Name value.
Use this parameter to add a new prefix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the prefix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.
Use this parameter to add a new suffix to the name. Will not change the original name value, simply add the suffix to the orignal name. Use the -Name parameter to adjust the entire name.

A description of the network's role within the logical interconnect. Accepted values in string format are:
• General • Management • VMMigration • FaultTolerance
Enable or Disable Smartlink within the Ethernet Network.
Enable or Disable Private Network within the Ethernet Network.
Preferred amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.
Maximum amount of bandwidth to assign, specified in Mbps.

The time in seconds the appliance waits before reconnecting to a link that was previously offline (Login redistribution). This interval prevents connection loss due to reconnecting to a link that is unstable (going online and offline repeatedly).

Used for login balancing when logins are not distributed evenly over the Fibre Channel links (for example, when an uplink that was down becomes available).
True: Login redistribution is initiated automatically when the link stability time expires. False: Login redistribution must be initiated manually.
Optional. Managed SAN Name or URI.
Network resource object.
The modified Network Resource Object or Update Task object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVNetwork "Net-11" | Set-HPOVNetwork -name NewNet-11 -Purpose Management -SmartLink $true -PrivateNetwork $false -TypicalBandwidth 500 -MaximumBandwidth 1500 Get the 'Net-11' Ethernet Network, pipe it to Set-HPOVNetwork to update values.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $fabricAManagedSan = Get-HPOVManagedSan "Fabric A" PS C:\> Get-HPOVNetwork "Prod Fabric A" | Set-HPOVNetwork -ManagedSan $fabricAManagedSan Update 'Prod Fabric A' FC Network with 'Fabric a' Managed SAN resource.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Modify the HPOneView POSH Prompt.

By default, the HP OneView POSH Library will change the prompt to display the following in the prompt:
[HPONEVIEW] user@appliance PS C:\>
The first part designates the module is currently loaded into the users PowerShell session. The second part shows which user account is connect to what appliance.
Using the -Disable switch, the default prompt will not be displayed when the module is loaded for the current user. This setting is configured on a per-user basis. When the prompt is disabled, you an use the Show-HPOVAppliance cmdlet to get the connected to information.
Enable the default prompt display for the current user.
Disable the default prompt display for the current user.
Enable the default prompt display for the current user.
Disable the default prompt display for the current user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
[HPONEVIEW]: [Not Connected] PS C:\Users\User> Set-HPOVPrompt -Disable PS C:\Users\User>
Disable the HPOneView POSH Library prompt for the current user, and return to original value.

maml:description.maml:para: Update existing resource(s).

This CMDLET will assist the user to update an existing resource. The resource should first be retrieved with a 'Get-HPOV[resourcename]' CMDLET. The PowerShell resource may then be modified, followed by this 'Set-HPOVResource' cmdlet.
The modified resource that is to be updated
Set to $true to force-update the resource. Not all resources support force-update.
The modified resource that is to be updated
Set to $true to force-update the resource. Not all resources support force-update.
Resource Object to modify by either using Send-HPOVRequest with the resource URI, or the resource GET CMDLET.
The modified resource or async task depending on the resource being modified.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $profile = Get-HPOVProfile 'Profile 1' PS C:\> $profile.name = "New Name" PS C:\> Set-HPOVResource $profile
Updates the name of the Server Profile resource.

maml:description.maml:para: Update SAN Manager configuration
Updates an existing SAN Manager configuration. Can update the hostname/IP Address and credentials. At least one optional parameter must be provided.
Name of the SAN Manager to update.
Updated Hostname or IP Address of the SAN Manager.
Updated TCP Port of the SAN Manager.
Updated Username used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.
Updated Password used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.
Name of the SAN Manager to update.
Updated Hostname or IP Address of the SAN Manager.
Updated TCP Port of the SAN Manager.
Updated Username used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.
Updated Password used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Update async task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $task = Set-HPOVSanManager -name BNA.contoso.com -hostname bna.newdomain.com PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task
Update the existing Brocade Network Advisor SAN Manager's hostname with the new value.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $task = Set-HPOVSanManager -name BNA.contoso.com -username newadmin -password updatedpassword PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task
Update the existing Brocade Network Advisor SAN Manager's username and password.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the power state of a server.
Set the power state of the server using the virtual power button.
Aliases [-name, -uri, -serverUri] The server object, URI or Name, or can be a Server Profile object.
Optional power state. Default is On, other option is Off

Optional setting to control the virtual power button. Default is MomentaryPress, other options are PressAndHold, ColdBoot and Reset
Current state powerState powerControl Result ------------- ---------- ------------ ------ On On MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On ColdBoot OK On On Reset OK On Off MomentaryPress OK (just have to assume that theres an OS on the server and it will power off the server someday) On Off PressAndHold OK On Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On MomentaryPress OK Off On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control
Aliases [-name, -uri, -serverUri] The server object, URI or Name, or can be a Server Profile object.
Optional power state. Default is On, other option is Off

Optional setting to control the virtual power button. Default is MomentaryPress, other options are PressAndHold, ColdBoot and Reset
Current state powerState powerControl Result ------------- ---------- ------------ ------ On On MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On ColdBoot OK On On Reset OK On Off MomentaryPress OK (just have to assume that theres an OS on the server and it will power off the server someday) On Off PressAndHold OK On Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On MomentaryPress OK Off On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control
Server Hardware Name
Server Hardware Resource
Async task that tracks the power state change

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVServer "Encl1, Bay 1" | Set-HPOVServerPower Power on the specific server device by passing the Server Object via pipeline to Set-HPOVServerPower.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVServer "Encl1, Bay 1" | Set-HPOVServerPower -powerState off -powerControl PressAndHold Power off the specific server device by passing the Server Object via pipeline to Set-HPOVServerPower.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $pro = Get-HPOVProfile "Profile1" PS C:\> Set-HPOVServerPower -serverUri $pro.configuration.assignedToServerUri -powerState On -powerControl MomentaryPress
Power on the specific server hardware by using the Server Profiles assignedToServerUri property.

maml:description.maml:para: Configure appliance SMTP Reporting settings.

This cmdlet configures the SMTP settings for the appliance. SMTP settings include deining the Sender EMAIL Address, SMTP relay server address, SMTP relay server TCP port, optional password, and if SMTP alerting is enabled or disabled.
Currently, HP OneView does not support Secure SMTP, even though the TCP Port can be modified. Using the SmtpPort parameter is to specify an alternate TCP Port than the default TCP/25.
Specify the Sender Email Address for the appliance.
Aliases [-server] Specify the SMTP Relay Server if DNS does not contain a valid DNS MX record for the sender email address domain name.
Aliases [-port] Provide an alternate TCP port number than the default SMTP port value 25/TCP.
Provide an SMTP Password to authenticate to the SMTP Server. This password will be sent in clear text to the SMTP server.
Enable SMTP Email Alerting
Specify the Sender Email Address for the appliance.
Aliases [-server] Specify the SMTP Relay Server if DNS does not contain a valid DNS MX record for the sender email address domain name.
Aliases [-port] Provide an alternate TCP port number than the default SMTP port value 25/TCP.
Provide an SMTP Password to authenticate to the SMTP Server. This password will be sent in clear text to the SMTP server.
Disable SMTP Email Alerting.
Specify the Sender Email Address for the appliance.
Aliases [-server] Specify the SMTP Relay Server if DNS does not contain a valid DNS MX record for the sender email address domain name.
Aliases [-port] Provide an alternate TCP port number than the default SMTP port value 25/TCP.
Provide an SMTP Password to authenticate to the SMTP Server. This password will be sent in clear text to the SMTP server.
Disable SMTP Email Alerting.
Enable SMTP Email Alerting

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: If successful, returns an async task resource that can be monitored with status and progress of the saved email notification operation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVSMTPConfig -SenderEmailAddress hpov-alerts@contoso.com -alertEmailEnabled Set the appliance's SMTP Sender Email Address to 'hpov-alerts@contoso.com' and enable SMTP Email Alerting.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVSMTPConfig -SenderEmailAddress hpov-alerts@contoso.com -alertEmailEnabled Set the appliance's SMTP Sender Email Address to 'hpov-alerts@contoso.com' and enable SMTP Email Alerting.

maml:description.maml:para: Set SNMP Read Community.

Set a new SNMP Read Community value on the appliance. Updating this value will cause the appliance to refresh the managed devices with the updated Read-Only SNMP Community string. This does not update the SNMP trap destination(s) for Logical Interconnects or Logical Interconnect Groups.
The name of the new SNMP Read-Only Community
The name of the new SNMP Read-Only Community

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVSnmpReadCommunity -name "MySNMPC0mmunity" Set the appliance SNMP Read Community string to the new value.

maml:description.maml:para: Set Storage Volume Template Global Policy

By default, Storage Volumes can be created without reference to a Storage Volume Template. This cmdlet will allow the administrator to change the global policy setting. Use with caution, as this will prevent copying Server Profiles that contain attached Storage Volumes.
Switch to enable the policy
Switch to disable the policy
Switch to enable the policy
Switch to disable the policy

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Returned boolean value after changing policy.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplatePolicy True
PS C:\> Set-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplatePolicy -disable Get the Storage Volume Template Global Policy setting, then disable it.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing Storage Volume resource.
This cmdlet will help modify an existing Storage Volume resource. Only the Volume Name, Description, Capcity, volume shared state and permenance can be modified.
Updated description for the volume.

Aliases [-size] New Max volume capacity in GB. Volume capacity can be increased to maximum of 16 TiB. Decreasing the capacity of volume is not supported.
Before increasing the capacity of fully provisioned volumes, ensure that the storage pool has enough capacity to support the operation. The update operation might fail if there is not enough space available in the storage pool.
e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private

If present, indicates that the volume will persist when the profile using this volume is deleted (Persistent Volume). If not, then the volume will be deleted when the profile using this volume is deleted (Ephemeral Volume).
Updated description for the volume.

Aliases [-size] New Max volume capacity in GB. Volume capacity can be increased to maximum of 16 TiB. Decreasing the capacity of volume is not supported.
Before increasing the capacity of fully provisioned volumes, ensure that the storage pool has enough capacity to support the operation. The update operation might fail if there is not enough space available in the storage pool.
e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private

If present, indicates that the volume will persist when the profile using this volume is deleted (Persistent Volume). If not, then the volume will be deleted when the profile using this volume is deleted (Ephemeral Volume).
Storage Pool Name or URI
Storage Pool resource object
Async create task

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVStorageVolume -sourceVolume ProdVol1 -Size 160 Update 'ProdVol1' volume size to 160GB.

maml:description.maml:para: Update current user account password.

This cmdlet provides the ability to update the current user account password. Only HP OneView appliance local account passwords will be changed. This cmdlet does not assist with modifying or updating an LDAP or Active Directory user account's password.
The current password of the user account. If omitted, the cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.
The new password to be set for the user account. If omitted, the cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.
The current password of the user account. If omitted, the cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.
The new password to be set for the user account. If omitted, the cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVUserPassword MyCurrentPass NewP@ssw0rd Update your HP OneView account password to the new value.

maml:description.maml:para: Assign or change roles for an existing user.
Changes current roles of a user with a given set of roles. It is not possible to modify roles of the built-in administrator, or your own user account.
The name of the user account to have a role assigned.

Array of roles for the user. May include one of more of:
• Infrastructure Administrator • Read Only • Backup Administrator • Network Administrator • Server Administrator • Storage Administrator
The name of the user account to have a role assigned.

Array of roles for the user. May include one of more of:
• Infrastructure Administrator • Read Only • Backup Administrator • Network Administrator • Server Administrator • Storage Administrator

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.
Updated user account with new role(s).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVUserRole -user Sally -roleName "Server Administrator" Set the Server Administrator role for Sally's user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing user account.

Modify or update an existing local user account on the management appliance. This cmdlet will not update the password or roles of the currently logged in user account. To update your HP OneView appliance local account's password, please use the Set-HPOVUserPassword cmdlet.
The name of the new user account to be modified.
OPTIONAL. New password for the user account. Passwords must be at least 8 characters.

maml:description.maml:para: Display HP OneView appliance connected to.

This cmdlet will show the connected appliance information. Will contain the connected user account and the appliance address. Can be used when the default prompt has been disabled with the Set-HPOVPrompt cmdlet.

PS C:\> Show-HPOVAppliance User : administrator Appliance : hpov.contoso.com
Display what appliance the library is connected to.

Generate firmware report

By specifying an Enclosure Group, all associated Enclosures will be included in the report.

maml:description.maml:para: List Directory Groups from the configured LDAP Directory.

This cmdlet will display the groups found when specifying the appropriate configured directory. The displayed Directory Groups can then be used to define new Directory Group Role assignment on the appliance with the New-HPOVLdapGroup cmdlet.
Aliases [-u] Username to authenticate with
Aliases [-p] User account password

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Show-HPOVLdapGroups -u 'Sarah Peterson' -d Domain1 Get list of Directory Groups from Domain1 and prompt for password.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------

PS C:\> $password = convertto-securestring -asplaintext "password123890" -force PS C:\> Show-HPOVLdapGroups -u 'Sarah Peterson' -p $password -d Domain99

maml:description.maml:para: Show the MAC Table for Logical Interconnect resource(s).

This cmdlet will help show the MAC Table of Logical Interconnect resources. The REST API currently limits the first 100 MAC addresses from the MAC table, regardless of the number of MAC Addresses learned in the table.
Use the -Network parameter to specify the Network Name to display learned MAC Addresses. You can export the results to a CSV file, by providing the full path and filename to export to, using the -ExportFile parameter.
To display the results in a formatted list, use the -List parameter.
Aliases [-name, -li] The Name, URI, Logical Interconnect Resource or an array of either to display the MAC Address tables from.
Provide the Network Name to filter the MAC Table results for.
Aliases [-x, -export] Export to a CSV, provide the full path and filename.
Display the results in a formatted table.
Aliases [-name, -li] The Name, URI, Logical Interconnect Resource or an array of either to display the MAC Address tables from.
Provide a MAC Address to locate in the MAC Table.

Display the results in a formatted table.
Aliases [-name, -li] The Name, URI, Logical Interconnect Resource or an array of either to display the MAC Address tables from.
Provide the Network Name to filter the MAC Table results for.
Provide a MAC Address to locate in the MAC Table.

Display the results in a formatted table.
Logical Inteconnect URI or Name
An Array of Logical Interconnect resource URI's, Names or Objects.
Logical Interconnect Resource Object
Collection of MAC Address Table entries.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Show-HPOVLogicalInterconnectMacTable Return as many MAC Addresses allowed by the API for all Logical Interconnect resources.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Show-HPOVLogicalInterconnectMacTable -network VLAN100 -list Done. 1 logical interconnect group(s) found. Done. 1 network resource(s) found.
Enclosure Interconnect Interface Address Type Network VLAN --------- ------------ --------- ------- ---- ------- ---- Encl1 interconnect 2 LAG 27 38:22:D6:35:5A:62 Learned VLAN100 30 Encl1 interconnect 1 LAG 26 38:22:D6:35:5A:62 Learned VLAN100 30 Encl1 interconnect 1 LAG 26 78:AC:C0:72:E5:D9 Learned VLAN100 30
Done. 3 mac table entry(ies) found.
Display all available MAC Addresses learned in 'VLAN100' network in all Logical Interconnect resources, and display in a formatted table.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Show-HPOVLogicalInterconnectMacTable -network VLAN100 -exportfile C:\reports\Encl1-LI_vlan100_mactable.csv Done. 1 logical interconnect group(s) found. Done. 1 network resource(s) found. Done. 3 mac table entry(ies) found.
Retrieve the available MAC Addresses learned in 'VLAN100' network, and export to C:\reports\Encl1-LI_vlan100_mactable.csv

Used to specify the applinace to connect to, if an existing connection isn't established from the Connect-HPOVMgmt cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop an HP OneView appliance.

This cmdlet will allow the administrator to stop/shutdown the appliance. Shutdown of the appliance will cause all users to be disconnected and all ongoing tasks to be interrupted.
Only the Inrfrastructure (Full) Administrator may restart the appliance.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Warning message the appliance is stopping
Generated error message

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Stop-HPOVAppliance Shutdown the appliance.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Stop-HPOVAppliance -confirm:$false Shutdown the appliance, disable confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Update or Refresh an enclosure.

This cmdlet will update or refresh an enclosure. An Enclosure Refresh will instruct HP OneView to go inventory the enclosure and update any missing management configurations. An Enclosure Update from EG will re-apply the Enclosure Group configuration for compliance.
Use the -Refresh switch for scenarios where adding an enclosure results in a warning or critical error when a BL server cannot be managed due to an existing _HPOneViewAdmin account that cannot be reset or too many HP SSO Certificates are configured (iLO supports no more than 5) and you have manually cleared the HP SSO list and/or removed the _HPOneViewAdmin account.
Optional. Provide the Enclosure name or [System.Array] of names to refresh/update.
Refresh the enclosure to fix configuration issues.
Optional. Wait for the update task to complete.
Optional. Provide the Enclosure name or [System.Array] of names to refresh/update.
Reapply the Enclosure Configuration.
Optional. Wait for the update task to complete.
Optional. Provide the Enclosure name or [System.Array] of names to refresh/update.
Aliases [-update] Update the Enclosure configuration from the associated Enclosure Group.
Optional. Wait for the update task to complete.
Optional. Provide the Enclosure name or [System.Array] of names to refresh/update.
Refresh the enclosure to fix configuration issues.
Aliases [-update] Update the Enclosure configuration from the associated Enclosure Group.
Reapply the Enclosure Configuration.
Optional. Wait for the update task to complete.
Single Enclosure resource.
Multiple Enclosure resources.
Async task Resource object for monitoring the enclosure import process.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-HPOVEnclosure -Refresh Refresh all available enclosures.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-HPOVEnclosure Enclosure1 -Refresh Refresh 'Enclosure1' enclosure.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-HPOVEnclosure -UpdateFromEG Re-apply Enclosure Group settings all available enclosures.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Update-HPOVEnclosure Enclosure1 -UpdateFromEG Re-apply Enclosure Group settings 'Enclosure1' enclosure.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a Logical Interconnect.

When a Logical Interconnect is inconsistent with its parent Logical Interconnect Group, it can be made consistent with this CMDLET. Updating the Logical Interconnect with its parent could cause an network outage depending on the changes about to be applied.
Aliases [-li, -uri] The Logical Interconnect object(s), name(s) or uris(s) to be updated.
Aliases [-li, -uri] The Logical Interconnect object(s), name(s) or uris(s) to be updated.
OPTIONAL. Switch to reapply the Logical Interconnect configuration. This does NOT update the Logical Interconnect from the parent Logical Interconnect Group.
Aliases [-li, -uri] The Logical Interconnect object(s), name(s) or uris(s) to be updated.
OPTIONAL. Switch to reapply the Logical Interconnect configuration. This does NOT update the Logical Interconnect from the parent Logical Interconnect Group.
Logical Interconnect Name or URI
Single Logical Interconnect resource object
Collection of Logical Interconnect Names, URIs or System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject
Single or Multiple async Update Task(s).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $task = Update-HPOVLogicalInterconnect -name Encl1-LI PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task
Perform an update of the Encl1-LI Logical Interconnect. Will be prompted for confirmation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Update-HPOVLogicalInterconnect -name Encl1-LI -confirm:$false PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task Perform an update of the Encl1-LI Logical Interconnect. Disable confirmation prompt.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVLogicalInterconnect | Update-HPOVLogicalInterconnect Search for all Logical Interconnects and update them.

maml:description.maml:para: Wait for Appliance services to start.

Internal module helper function to wait for the appliance services to start. This helper function will be called by Send-HPOVRequest when the [System.Net.WebRequest] GetResponse() client generates an [Net.WebException] exception. Then, this function will be called to provide the caller with an indication that the appliance is starting its services. This will display two prompts:
1. An initial text-based progress bar while the System.Net.WebRequest is able to access the web service on the appliance to begin polling for service startup status. 2. Write-Progress indicator displaying the overall service startup.
If any service fails to startup, this function will cause a terminating error, informing the caller to go visit the appliance kiosk console to get more information about the startup error.
When the appliance successfully starts, this function will return.
Specify the appliance FQDN or IP Address without a valid connection by using Connect-HPOVMgmt exists.
Specify the appliance FQDN or IP Address without a valid connection by using Connect-HPOVMgmt exists.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: The Write-Progress cmdlet is used to display the startup progress.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVApplianceStart -Appliance appliance.contoso.com Wait for the appliance to start, and specify the appliance name.

maml:description.maml:para: Wait for a task to complete.

HP OneView utilizes a task subsystem for operations that will take longer than 200ms, and will execute them Asyncrounously. An async task resource object is created and returned to the caller once the request has passed validation.
This blocking cmdlet assists a caller with monitoring a specific task resource, and will wait for the given task to "complete" (get to a terminal state, including error) or timeout. The cmdlet accepts either the task URI or resource object via pipeline.
Once the task is no longer in a running state, the cmlet will return the task resource object. The caller should examine the taskState property/key for the final task status.
Aliases [-taskUri] The uri of the task resource to wait for.
The timespan to wait for the task to complete. Default is to wait for 20 minutes.
Aliases [-taskUri] The uri of the task resource to wait for.
The timespan to wait for the task to complete. Default is to wait for 20 minutes.
Task URI
Task resource object.
The finished Task object that includes the task result.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete /rest/tasks/F08EE040-DBA7-4806-BB62-993DD0CB4250 PS C:\> Waiting for task to complete...Task completed successfully! Wait for task to complete.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task -timeout (New-TimeSpan -minute 10) PS C:\> Waiting for task to complete...Task completed successfully! Wait for task to complete, modifying the default timeout to 10 minutes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $svr = Get-HPOVServer "ServerA" PS C:\> $taskResults = New-HPOVProfile -name "Profile 1" -server $svr | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete Retreive the server details for ServerA, create a Server Profile and pass via pipeline the task resource object.

maml:description.maml:para: Wait for a task to start.
Wait for the given task to "start" (get beyond validation phase) or timeout
Aliases [-taskuri] The uri or object of the task resource to wait for.
The time or object to wait for the task to start. Default is to wait for 20 minutes.
Aliases [-taskuri] The uri or object of the task resource to wait for.
The time or object to wait for the task to start. Default is to wait for 20 minutes.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Task completion or error message.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskstart /rest/tasks/F08EE040-DBA7-4806-BB62-993DD0CB4250 Wait for task to start
